entry.et: Middle English ech, from Old English ǣlc; akin to Old High German iogilīh each; both from West Germanic *aiw- ever, always (whence Old English ā always) + *galīkaz having the same form, like (whence Old English gelīc like) aye, like

def.dt: :being one of two or more distinct individuals having a similar relation and often constituting an aggregate
:to or for each :apiece cost a dollar each
:each of two or more in reciprocal action or relation looked at each other in surprise

entry.pt: Some handbooks and textbooks recommend that each other be restricted to reference to two and one another to reference to three or more. The distinction, while neat, is not observed in actual usage. Each other and one another are used interchangeably by good writers and have been since at least the 16th century.

entry.et: Middle English throte, from Old English; akin to Old High German drozza throat

def.dt: :the part of the neck in front of the spinal column
:the passage through the neck to the stomach and lungs
:something resembling the throat especially in being an entrance, a passageway, a constriction, or a narrowed part: as
:the orifice of a tubular organ especially of a plant
:the opening in the vamp of a shoe at the instep
:the part of a tennis racket that connects the head with the shaft
:the curved part of an anchor's arm where it joins the shank see anchor illustration
